text: Hi, everyone.
My name is Malissa Alinor.

So to begin, I want to tell
you a story about two people.
Susan is a Black woman.

And when she found out
that she was accepted

into the top university
of her state,

she was overjoyed, as any
high school senior would be.

When one of her
teachers found out,

he decided to tell her in
front of her entire class

that the only reason
that she was admitted

is because the university
needed to meet a racial quota.
Jerry is a Black man.

When he got the call that
he was going to be promoted,
he was ecstatic.

But that excitement
quickly soured

when one of his
white colleagues,

who had also wanted
the promotion,

told him that she
would never be promoted
because she's a white woman.

So Susan and Jerry's
stories are real.

And they are reflective
of the kinds of competency

microaggressions that
Black professionals
report experiencing at work.

And so I define competency
microaggressions

as comments and
behaviors directed

toward low-status
groups that reveal

low expectations of
their abilities, beliefs

that workers are Affirmative
Action hires, or surprise when
workers demonstrate competency.

And so these can
also be experienced

by other marginalized
groups, such as women
and disabled people.

And so there is a lot of
emotional labor involved
in handling microaggressions.

So on the one hand,
Black people want

to avoid being stereotyped as
the angry Black person at work.

So when they deal
with microaggression,

they tend to use
emotional restraints

and find ways to react in
a more professional way.

However on the other
hand, responding

in a way that does not
show negative emotion

can also end up sustaining
racial inequality, which

ends up in there being
a double-bind where

Black workers may end up being
harmed by the way they respond

to competency
microaggressions no matter
how they choose to react.

And so I wanted to better
understand this puzzle

by finding out how
microaggressions are affecting
Black people in real-time.

In particular, I looked
at the kinds of comments

they make in
response, the emotions

that they report
feeling, and then

are they're willing to accept
influence from the offender?

And so I conducted an
experimental research design,

and I crowdsourced a sample
of 295 Black men and women,

and then they completed a
workplace decision-making

task, which is a
measure of deference.

So depending on the condition
that they were randomly

assigned, they received
one of two messages

from a fictitious white partner
who they thought was real.

So if they received the
competency microaggression,

they received the
message, "They'll

probably pick you as the leader
because you're Black, lol."

And this is a very
common types of comment

that Black professionals
report experiencing.

And they have the opportunity
to message their partner back,

and in the control, they
were told this study is not
too bad so far.
And so what did I find?

So first, I'll talk
about responses.

I coded the responses
in the chat box

to whether or not they were
more conflict-avoidant or not as
conflict-avoidant.

And I found that workers who
experienced the competency

microaggression were more likely
to respond with comments that

were more conflict-avoidant,
like "lol, we will see,"
or, "That's quite funny."

And so then, did their
emotions map onto that?

And I found that those who
experienced the microaggression
reported more negative emotion.

So there's this emotional
labor in real-time.

And then they were also less
likely to accept influence.

And I also looked at
how many people end up

reporting the microaggression
at the end of the study.

I found that only 29% of workers
who experienced it actually
reported it.

And so the implications
of my study

is that we may think that
choosing to not defer

may benefit Black employees,
but in the long-run

it may harm them
because they're not

being able to be used a rational
objective for decision-making,

and then they also
may end up being angry

or labeled angry or
difficult to work with.

And then on the other hand,
showing greater deference

may not be a better
solution because it ends up

leaving microaggressions, those
conditions under which they
occur, unchallenged.
So that's it.
I beat the gong.
[APPLAUSE]
